title: Cardiac Tamponade from Penetrating Trauma
diagnosis_topic: Pericardial tamponade secondary to stab wound to the chest
setup_script: “A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the left precordium. He is lethargic and complains of chest pressure. There is a 3 cm stab wound over the fifth intercostal space. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 85/60 mmHg, HR 130 bpm, RR 30/min, SpO₂ 92% on oxygen.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident examines the patient further
dynamic_flow.reply: Distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds are noted.
Pericardial view demonstrates large pericardial effusion with right atrial collapse.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates IV fluid resuscitation
If resident requests chest X-ray instead of FAST
dynamic_flow.reply: Chest X-ray shows enlarged cardiac silhouette but patient becomes increasingly hypotensive.
Patient deteriorates to pulseless electrical activity.
Needle aspiration yields non-clotting dark blood; blood pressure improves temporarily.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about definitive management
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient requires operative exploration for repair of cardiac injury.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident calls for operating room thoracotomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Median sternotomy reveals right ventricular laceration with active bleeding; clot evacuated.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative steps
dynamic_flow.reply: Please describe your operative approach to repair this cardiac injury.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides correct repair steps
dynamic_flow.reply: Hemodynamics stabilize after repair of right ventricular laceration and pericardial decompression.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides incomplete or delayed repair
dynamic_flow.reply: Persistent hypotension and bleeding continue, requiring further operative intervention.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inquires about ED thoracotomy indications
dynamic_flow.reply: Penetrating chest trauma with witnessed signs of life and loss of pulses is an indication.
Patient is admitted to ICU; monitored for arrhythmias, bleeding, and recurrent tamponade.
Contaminated pericardial blood is not reinfused; cross-matched blood transfusion is required.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of obstructive shock due to cardiac tamponade
Use of FAST to identify pericardial effusion
Timely definitive surgical repair with sternotomy
Ability to describe operative steps for cardiac repair

anchors.1: Fails to recognize tamponade, misattributes symptoms
anchors.2: Delayed or incomplete differential, overlooks key findings
anchors.3: Considers tamponade but omits important alternatives
anchors.4: Comprehensive differential including tamponade with systematic reasoning
anchors.5: Rapidly identifies tamponade, articulates complete differential with supporting/refuting data

anchors.1: Fails to act on instability, inappropriate delays
anchors.2: Recognizes urgency but delays or orders inappropriate tests
anchors.3: Initiates management but misses timing or steps
anchors.4: Prioritizes resuscitation, diagnostics, and operative therapy appropriately
anchors.5: Anticipates complications, coordinates care, makes timely decisions throughout

anchors.2: Provides information but lacks clarity or structure
anchors.3: Clear communication of findings and plan, but incomplete engagement
anchors.4: Logical, structured, empathetic communication with team and patient
anchors.5: Succinct, compassionate, anticipates information needs of all parties

anchors.1: No knowledge of operative management for tamponade
anchors.2: Identifies operative options but with major errors in approach
anchors.3: Describes some operative steps but with omissions (e.g., exposure, control, repair technique)
anchors.4: Correctly details operative steps for sternotomy, evacuation, and ventricular repair with good technical sequence
anchors.5: Mastery of operative technique, including exposure, cardiac control, repair methods (pledgeted sutures, temporary control), perioperative considerations, and complication management

resident_feedback_template:
Strengths:You promptly recognized obstructive shock and used the FAST exam appropriately. Your ability to initiate temporizing measures and progress to definitive operative management was appropriate. You described key operative steps in cardiac repair clearly.
Areas for Improvement:In future, ensure that you consistently outline the complete sequence of operative management, including exposure, bleeding control, and repair technique. Earlier discussion of ED thoracotomy indications would also strengthen your performance.
Suggested Reading Topics:- Operative Repair of Penetrating Cardiac Trauma (SCORE)- Techniques in Cardiac Injury Management (ACS/ASE Trauma Manual)- Emergency Department Thoracotomy: Indications and Outcomes (EAST Guidelines)
